abstract.p: Letter from Al Magary comments on Aug 17 article on iPAQ IA-I Internet appliance

block.p: ''Appliance With a Purpose'' (State of the Art, Aug. 17), about the iPAQ IA-1 Internet appliance, says the role model for such appliances is the television because it doesn't require ''a lot of technical hocus-pocus.'' I've been programming VCR's since the early 1980's, but at least 1 time out of 10, when I've finished programming, I forget to turn off the VCR so it can come on automatically at the specified time. I forget because it's easy to forget and, in any case, counterintuitive to turn off something so that it will work.

I forget because it's easy to forget and, in any case, counterintuitive to turn off something so that it will work.

When we refinished the hardwood in the living room the other week, I had to unplug the spaghetti of wiring behind the TV cart. Later, of course, I plugged things back in, but the setup -- which included three cables going into one connecting device -- didn't work correctly until I played around with the wiring and the connectors and the buttons and the on-screen setup. TV watching is too complicated! Give me computing!
